item.content:encoded:
This week we have Makerthon!

It is a warm-up before our final projects.

In the beginning of the week we had a brainstorming session on sharing various ideas of what could be done during the week. Some of the ideas were:

  • to make a todolist that can be used by several people, with shared goals,
  • to write a twitter with messenger,
  • do something Halloween themed,
  • to make a plug-in for Chrome that will let you close opened windows/tabs by whistling,
  • to make an on-line game,
  • make it possible to open the entrance door from Slack, and many-many others.

I loved the idea about whistling, but I had no clue how to approach it and if it is even doable!

There were two more guys who loved the idea and we formed an absolute dream team!

Guess what? We did it!

Try it here. Add it to Chrome, open a new window (not a tab, sorry still have a couple of bugs to catch), allow mic, open more tabs, browse in Internet and if someone enters the room... whistle! All tabs will be closed in a moment! Of course you were not procrastinating in Facebook!

  • Well-grounded Rubyist by David A. Black (pre-course)
  • Practical object oriented design in Ruby aka POODR by great Sandi Metz (1st and 2nd weeks)
  • Jump start Sinatra by Darren Jones (3rd and 4th weeks)
  • HTML/CSS and JavaScript/jQuery by Jon Duckett (5th and 6th weeks) - good books, but too many pictures, and as a result no kindle version and too heavy to carry
  • Ruby on rails tutorial by Michael Hartl and The rails 4 way by Obie Fernandez, Kevin Faustino (7th week)
  • AngularJS Up & Running by Shyam Seshadri, Brad Green (8th week)

Have a good read!

item.dc:creator: Yana Proskurina
item.content:encoded:
Today Evgeniy (Makers founder and CEO) gave a great talk on Teal companies.

The talk was based on Frédéric Laloux book Reinventing Organizations.

In this book the author uses a colour scheme to describe the historical development of human organizations: Red > Orange > Green > Teal.

Laloux lists three breakthroughs of Teal organizations:

Self-management: driven by peer relationships

Wholeness: involving the whole person at work

Evolutionary purpose: let the organization adapt and grow, not be driven

In simple words Teal companies are based on trust, responsible and proactive approach to work. No one tells you what to do and you do things only if you believe that these things are worth doing. And at work you are the same person as in "real" life, because work IS your real life and you do not have to pretend to be someone else. So the main idea is to work and enjoy life at the same time.

Sounds like a dream! But it is real.

It seems that Makers Academy is fantastic not only for students but also for people who work there.

item.dc:creator: Yana Proskurina
item.content:encoded:
This is a short addition to my previous post.

So, you are deploying your app to heroku.

But you do not want to push bower_components folder to github or heroku (so bower_components is in your .gitignore file).

How to make heroku run bower install and install bower_components to the right folder?

3 simple steps:

1) Include bower as dependency into your package.json file like this: 

  "dependencies": {
    "bower": "^1.6.3"
  }

It will tell heroku to install bower in the first place.

2) In the same package.json file tell heroku to run bower install. You do it like this:

  "scripts": {
    "postinstall": "bower install"
  },

3) Indicate where you want bower_components to be installed. By default this folder will appear in your root directory, if you want it to be in another place you need .bowerrc file.

For example, if you want it to be in public folder you indicate it in your .bowerrc file:

{
  "directory" : "public/bower_components"
}

Now heroku knows what to do!

item.dc:creator: Yana Proskurina
item.content:encoded:
Now I have my little, but nice and working one page web-site built with Angular, but it is working only in my browser.

Of course I want to deploy it to heroku. But I need to build a server first.

I could do it with Sinatra, but it is JS and Angular... So why not use NodeJS and Express. It seems more natural, right?

And it is easy!

So my app now is something like this: 

project  
|___.git(folder, lots of things going on here)
|___bower_components
|___node_modules
|
|___js
|   |__app.js
|   |__gitUserSearchController.js
|   |__searchFactory.js
|
|___test
|   |__gitSearchController.spec.js
|   |__karma.conf.js
|   |__searchFactory.spec.js
|
|___bower.json
|___index.html
|___package.json

First, install node and express.

And then in a root directory make a little server, for example, server.js, that looks something like this: 

var express = require('express');  
var app = express();

app.use(express.static(__dirname + '/public'));

app.get('/', function (req, res) {  
  res.sendFile(__dirname + '/index.html');
});

app.listen(process.env.PORT || 3000, function() {  
  console.log("listening on 3000");
});

That's it!

Most of it is just a simple example from here.

Things I changed are:

  • made direct reference to my index.html file (yes, there in no need to render html here!),
  • added process.env.PORT (for Heroku).

I also moved my js and bower_components folders to public folder (no need to even change pathes to files in index.html file! Though if you have secrets in js folder, don't forget to change path in .gitignore).

Now do node server.js and enjoy!

While deploying to heroku remember about

  • dependencies to be listed (and installed)
  • secrets
  • not deploying node_modules and bower_components.

item.dc:creator: Yana Proskurina
item.content:encoded:
The end of the week and weekend I spent working mostly on our bowling challenge.

It seemed ok in the beginning, code looked nice, then became heavier, then unreadable and then... I followed one of our coaches advice: "It is always fun to throw everything away and start from the beginning".

I had another idea on how to build it. The task became ok again, I wrote a nice engine, it all worked so nicely, that I decided to make an interface. That was not wise. I stopped sleeping at nights. I even came back to the first version of the code, but it made things even worse. I went to a long long walk to a park. And the next day again.

And then suddenly I had a solution. And it worked! And it involved only reasonable amount of code! And I even had some time to write this post!

But the lesson was learned - if you need an interface, think about it from the beginning.

item.dc:creator: Yana Proskurina
item.content:encoded:
Well, obviously I do not follow my plan...

At least I do not post here every day, but that is because I learn so many things simultaneously!

New knowledge for the last 3 days in few words:

MEAN stays for Mongo, Express, Angular and Node.

Node helps you to run your JS program using terminal, just print node <filename.js> in command line. If you type node in terminal you can play with JS the same way as you play with Ruby using irb (but I already got used to console and console.log()). It is not a server, but you can create one with it. And everything is in JS! So no need to switch from JS to Ruby (or another language) and back. An important thing about Node is that it is asynchronous, which makes it very effective. But you have to use callbacks for that, and it is not so straight forward in the beginning.

Express is something like Sinatra, but for Node JS. It seems easier and more intuitive, but may be it is because we already learned how to deal with Sinatra. For express template engine is not needed, it can handle html files directly, it is good for simple projects but for more complicated you can use Jade or ejs (they are like erb for ruby).

Mongo is a non SQL database, it stores information as JSON, and it seems a bit chaotic, but may be it is not, I just started to play with it.

And Angular... I am not sure yet. We will have the whole week dedicated to it, so I will write about it later.

Here is fantastic blog post on the topic.
